comments.commentBody:
Better to tell her to pick her dates very, very carefully, communicate clearly, and discourage anyone else drinking on her dates. It's KNOWN people who are the typical rapist, not strangers at a club where she probably would have that buddy. And, really, a buddy on a date?

Avoiding binge drinking, however, has a lot of other benefits that recommend it.

Welcome back, paulymath, we missed you big fella!

Howie

That's when the predators come out to play?

Rape occurs because of the presence of a rapist.

You are absolutely right.  In my college town, every week, there are crimes committed against women between the hours of 2am and 3am when the bars have closed and they make their way home.  Predictable, and why?

If only every parent gave his/her child a copy of Carl Becker's "Freedom and Responsibility" delivered at Cornell in 1940 before they left home for college and pleaded with them to read it, there'd be a lot less parental guilt around when something terrible happens to their child.

"Some men will rape, given the opportunity. Don't give it to them."

And there's the crux of the problem. "Don't give it to them"? Really? This puts 100% of the onus on the woman. If a man rapes a woman, the conversation's undertone is "she gave him the opportunity to rape her".

Language shifts the blame. This is victim-blaming.

It's like looking both ways before you cross the street. You have the right of way, but if you want to arrive safely, exercise prudence. That doesn't excuse the driver who kills you, but what is your goal: to hold someone responsible for killing you, or to remain alive?

No one ever needs to get blind drunk, drunk at all, or even to reach the point where inhibitions begin to be relaxed. Limit alcohol to one glass of wine, with dinner. If you need more than that, you have an alcohol problem.

Some men will rape, given the opportunity. Don't give it to them.

Incorrect. A drunk man incapable of consent can be raped. A good number are. It's the most common way men are raped by both men and women, actually.

Practically, it's even harder for a man to bring a rape charge and make it stick than a woman. However, legally, men are equally protected. Rape and sexual assault laws removed mentions of gender awhile ago.

Sorry M, but according to a 2007 paper written by the National District Attorneys Association "most States do not recognize voluntary intoxication as a defense."  Therefore, although both party's may be "voluntarily intoxicated" the man cannot claim he lacked the requisite mental capacity necessary for "informed consent," as opposed to the "victim" where the charges are based entirely on her inability for "informed consent."

It is not a defense. It is a reason a man can bring a rape charge against another person.

It shouldn't be a defense, because the "I was drunk" 'defense' is the most common one of serial rapists. Even very, very drunk people can tell when someone doesn't want to do something or is passed out, and if a man was too drunk to be able to tell what is or is not consent, he would also be too drunk to undress a woman and/or get an erection. You're right that being drunk is not a defense for raping someone, and that's because it is never a valid one.

Simple hypocrisy in the law: a woman who is drunk and is "raped" is deemed to be incapable of "informed consent," yet if a man is equally intoxicated he is denied access to this same legal protection.

Your argument contains several logical fallacies.

First, you equate the suggestion that women avoid becoming blind drunk through binge drinking with the suggestion that they become teetotalers. This is a false dichotomy. There is a middle ground where all but the most hardened alcoholic women can drink in moderation and thus decrease the chance that they will be sexually assaulted. (For those who cannot drink in moderation, alcohol should be avoided for health reasons even if there is on risk of rape.) So no, it is not being suggested that women become teetotalers, or lock themselves up in a convent. Just that they drink responsibly.

Second, you state that in focusing on the actions of the victim the role of the perpetrator is ignored. Again, a false dichotomy. The two are not mutually exclusive. Suggesting that people lock their doors and keep their valuables in a safety deposit box does not imply that we are soft on criminals, it simply implies that we realize that there are criminals among us and it is thus prudent to take reasonable precautions.

With a devastating crime like rape, all avenues of prevention should be pursued simultaneously. As long as there are sexual predators out there, training the potential victims how to protect themselves is a no-brainer. And one good way to do this is to suggest they avoid getting blind drunk.

But another specific type of regulation might be among the most efficient way of reducing emissions, at least in part, and that is using law, both regulation and legal precedent arising from lawsuit, to internalize for the producers of fossil fuels and those who use them the negative externalities of such production and use. I know that this overlaps with taxes, but some internalizations would be unique and highly efficient. For example, requiring fracking firms to bear the full costs and full risks of liability arising from fracking and requiring coal-fired electric and other plants to bear the full external costs of pollution, including but not limited to, the damage to people’s health caused by such pollution.

Finally, one could design a legal tariff on imports of goods from nations that refuse to reduce CO2 in concert with other nations, if the costs of domestic CO2 taxes and/or regulation at least matched the tariff, so that such a tariff doesn’t give competitive advantage to the imposer’s exports and/or domestic industries in its domestic markets. But your cap-and-trade idea is good too, so that there is an incentive to reduce emission and profit from selling unneeded permits. But cap-and-trade and tariffs are not mutually exclusive and could compliment each other as part of regime or convention to reduce CO2 emissions.

I read your review, which made me order "The Climate Casino . . . ." But here are a couple of quick thoughts about the your review:

Both Professor Nordhaus and Rex Tillerson, Exxon's CEO, are sanguine about geoengineering. Tillerson, about 16 months ago, abandoned Exxon's long-held position that climate change is speculative at best, and has accepted that climate change is real but that we can adapt. "In a speech Wednesday, Tillerson acknowledged that burning of fossil fuels is warming the planet, but said society will be able to adapt." "Exxon's CEO: Climate, energy fears overblown," Yahoo News, 27 June 2012.

However, I doubt that such optimism is warranted. First, there has never been such an attempt at planetary geoengineering, at least not on this planet. And so there is no reason to think that we could do it on the first try to avert a catastrophe. And then there is the significant risks of unintended and dangerous consequences from trying to modify our planet's atmosphere on a planetary scale.

To tax or regulate? Well, of course, we should do both, each were it is most efficient at reducing emissions of greenhouse gases and each in the forms that best suit the task. So perhaps we would reduce emission from coal-fired power plants with both regulation and prohibitive taxes, while using economically rational taxes on CO2 else where. But you are right that a tax on CO2 is a nonstarter in America's present political climate. (cont.)

Yeah ... sex drives in men and women aren't actually very different. Very variable, sure, but not really any higher for men than women. That's a lie we've told ourselves a lot, but it's simply not true.

Men don't make that mistake, either. They well recognize what no means. In every other non-sexual context, women's noes are well understood by men (this has been borne out by sociological research). Men choose to ignore women's noes, but they understand them. They don't make that mistake. It's just a handy excuse to avoid prosecution, and we as a society really truly can stop buying that nonsense.

Pretending to think sexual contact is wanted is also still called rape.

Re: Comment by "M"

THE SEXUAL DICHOTOMY

Two somewhat antithetical trends are simultaneously going on concerning sexuality: more freedom and experimentation coupled with a stricter view of erotic morality.

[Just observing and not judging.]

LET'S STOP PATRONIZING TOUNG WOMEN

If you're a woman and old enough to drink do appreciate the hyper sexual drive of young men. It is possible that when dead drunk, a man will actually mistake or pretend to think that sexual contact is wanted.

So, use common sense as to with whom you spend your time with and use your head to calculate how many units of alcohol you have consumed. Each person has a given limit -- learn yours. Or abstain.

If you're over 21, you should have learned from the Bible or Charles Darwin: procreate, procreate, procreate... But, now having sex is up to you.

Russia has been trying to ignore Western influence for a long time.  It hasn't worked all that well.  Perhaps the only way we can really help LGBT people in Russia, short of media and movies, is to continue the work here so that one day there will be no reason why there couldn't be an LGBT president.  There are some communities here in the USA that need some real work.

We rarely heard of rape years ago because it wasn't reported, not because it wasn't happening. Victims knew they wouldn't get justice and would only be victimized further if they came forward. Rape is nothing new.

"Years ago we rarely heard of rape on college campuses, or the military, to the extent that congressional hearings and challenge to the chain of command were needed."

That may be true for the military but we've been talking about campus rape for decades going back to the famous 1987 study by Mary Koss which brought us the some what misleading '1 in 4' statistic for female victimization over 4 years of college. We've only had about a decade of mainstream focus on rape in the military which also is burdened with a heavy drinking group of young adults just like on college campuses. The same advice applies.

We don't have a epidemic of sexual violence. Relative to the total sexually active population along with total incidences of sex it's rare. In a given year it impacts about 1% of the population.

It's an ongoing intractable issue of a otherwise pleasurable activity people normally engage becoming a crime for lack of consent. It's notoriously hard to prove and practically speaking not preventable. Eliminating crime is a unrealistic goal and reasonable focus on education, prevention, and punishment should be sufficient. None of that will ever be a provide us absolute control over every human being in our free society.

This is a sensible essay. Just because women have unfairly & traditionally been blamed for rape, letting the man off the hook, does not mean that they are not responsible for increasing the chances of assault. That's why we have arguments. It's not 1 or the other.

Some women maybe prefer to suffer the consequences of risky behavior than to have their independence compromised, as they see it. So gender equality can lead to destructive behavior. And what are the reactions of some of the men they meet? They see this as permission.

Meanwhile he Centers for Disease Control said in 2010 that we have an epidemic of sexual violence, and that includes intimate partners. Years ago we rarely heard of rape on college campuses, or the military, to the extent that congressional hearings and challenge to the chain of command were needed.

Wags, As your user name suggests, you're noted in WP for your rapire wit!

Howie TBOQ

False equivalence strikes again. This is not a law "Viewed as anti-gay in the West.". It IS an anti-gay law. The people who wrote it say as much. A law that is against a group is, by the very definition, ANTI. Please just stop the quibbling. It is not unbalanced to call something what it is.

Well when people in the United States can be fired for being gay, I think we have a long way to go. Obviously we are way ahead of Russia, but that is hardly a stringent test.

I am glad to see the swelling of states accepting gay marriage, but when will gay people have full equality?

I agree that he will be a great symbol. I hope that he and all the attendees come home again safe and sound.

It is truly amazing how high school (typical class size 30) is free and University (huge classes sizes) costs a fortune.

Only in the good old exceptional USA.

LeapyL, You wouldn't want to get all TANGOED up with WS, for the simple reason I hear tell he has two left feet!

WHH

Outside of expulsion and reporting to the police, colleges have little other recourse for dealing with rapists.

And that is really how it should be. Colleges are not there to be courts of law-they are there to educate and part of educating is teaching rapists "If you do this, there will be consequences."

The Opinion editors chose to cite three studies which examine the association between drinking and sexual violence, but failed to cite David Lisak's research based on interviews with 2,000 male college students, which found that serial rapists account for 90% of campus rapes. Correlation is not causation: drinking does not cause rape - rapists cause rape.

Re: "unwillingness to confront" - Are college students who have been found responsible for sexual assault ever required to participate in specialized sexual offender treatment? (See: International Association for the Treatment of Sexual Offenders for standards of care.) This would seem a critical step in getting men to stop raping - require expert evaluation for sexual pathology, followed by specialized therapy focused on preventing sexual re-offense.

In practice, I doubt that the direct message: "You must learn to stop raping by attending to your problems with raping people" is ever part of the sanctions placed on college offenders. My guess is that the of few college offenders that do get sanctioned, some may be directed to general counseling, domestic violence, or alcohol prevention programs, but, do any ever get sent to sex offender programs like perpetrators sentenced in the criminal justice system?

I think we have a Nancy Reagan approach to preventing rape - we are telling our rapists "if you get caught raping we will punish you so just stop", and we are telling our victims "just say no". It is not working.
You had the wrong kind of people as married friends.  The whole has other people in it besides those idiots.

I have also been shocked at this phenomenon when my husband travels for work (internationally for 2 or 3 weeks at a time).  We don't always know in advance exactly what days he is flying, and I go ahead and make plans regardless.  When I show up solo to an evening event, people are shocked and confused why I still came and didn't stay home.  Some say hurtful things.  I know they are very uneasy, but I'm still shocked when it happens.  I also noticed at times that I become invisible at the dinner table - everyone else is asked what their vacation plans are, what their latest news is...it's like I'm the child hoping to get a bit of attention at the adults table.

The key is to never be perceived as a threat to the married wives. It takes a lot of hand-smacking, but once you are seen as totally non-threatening because you respect their marriages, you're in. I have actually had wives ask me to accompany their husbands on outings they may be unable to attend...

It also happens when you divorce. It seems that a single divorced woman is seen as a threat. The married men want to be gentlemen and open doors, bring drinks, etc. but they are concerned that their wives will not understand. The wives see the single woman as a real threat especially if she is nice looking.
I just had to find other single friends since my married friends no longer were comfortable around me.

This is a very well expressed essay. It gets to the distorted, sick psychology that causes sexual assault and often excuses it. Despite women's equality, there is much in our society that adds to the male sense of privilege. But some women collaborate in their own problems.

Sure, place blame on these male attitudes you vividly describe. But to leave it at that is unrealistic. Drinking is seen as cool, and in some circles, the main social activity, with plenty of social pressure. It may not directly cause rape, but heavy drinking will increase the chances of rape, given certain dynamics between the sexes. It's not just one factor. That's not the same as taking the blame off men, at all.

Women who don't frequently include heavy drinking with social activities, likely have less threat against them from exaggerated male egos.

In any situation of exploitation, mistreatment or power imbalance, the weaker party must minimize adding to their victimization.
I think she means guys who are raped by other guys.

Yes, many people in high places take no responsibility for their actions and no one holds them accountable. That's why I'm going to push for more investigations into Benghazi right after the Bush/Cheney 911 and Iraq war trials are over.

t.h. - Yes, reading to babies (even in the womb) is fantastic. The higher level children's book authors (Sendak, Juster, Ungerer) have rich vocabulary. Check out this article and please share it.

http://papagreenbean.blogspot.com/2013/07/reading-aloud-allowed.html

I didn't see anything in this article about the importance of reading to your small child, even before he or she can speak.  Many, if not most, children's books have richer language and more varied vocabulary than what most college-educated adults use in casual conversation.  Just think of "Where the Wild Things Are":  "...and they rolled their terrible eyes and gnashed their terrible teeth and showed their terrible claws..."

When my first son was born everyone and everybody told me to talk to my child. But it was hard to do. I was home alone, too self-aware, with raging postpartum depression to boot. It took a while to loosen up and start talking. So before all you commenters judge those terrible 'non speaking uncultural working moms' I urge you to think of what exhaustion and depression does to people.

Uh, maybe it's because Obama came to tour the storm-ravaged areas the next day, and immediately released federal funds for the relief of the victims, while Bush waited 5 days to do a helicopter flyover of New Orleans--and even then only after public outcry over his indifference to the suffering of the people.

As is typical in the sale and purchase of a business, Bank of America, as buyer, assumed all liabilities when it purchased Countrywide.

Typically a bank (or any other business) will conduct extensive due diligence to determine the value of the assets and the extent of liabilities, including potential liabilities. Presumably Bank of America did its due diligence when it acquired Countrywide and assessed the likelihood of legal issues in regards to Countrywide's mortgage portfolio. The price of the acquisition reflected BofA's assessment of liability.

Furthermore, even if a bank or business is under heavy pressure from the government to buy a troubled business, the bank or business can and does say no - Lehmann Bros as an example. And even if it says yes - it is often conditioned on specific government agreements regarding supervisory actions in the future.

Hope this helps you.
@James B:  You are seriously mis-informed:  Tap water that catches fire has been known going back to the 1800's, if not before.
